answers: A Thousand Plateaus [or Mille Plateaux; prompt on Capitalism and Schizophrenia]
parts: Identify these beings. Peter Singer wrote a book advocating for "liberation" for these beings, whose rights are also advocated for by PETA.
This philosopher considered the problem of "facts beyond the reach of human concepts" in his paper "What Is it Like to Be a Bat?"

This text distinguishes between "Oedipal," "State," and "demonic" modes of animals in its analysis of "becoming-animal." The chapters of this text by Gilles Deleuze and Felix Guattari can be read in any order.

answers: fathers [accept Fathers and Sons; accept answers like dads; prompt on parent]
parts: Identify this author of the long autofictional series My Struggle.

The first book in Knausgård's My Struggle ends with the death of an abusive character with this relation to the author. Ivan Turgenev's novel about the nihilist Bazarov is titled for these people "and sons."
Knausgård is an author from this country. Another author from this country, Knut Hamsun, wrote the novel Hunger.

answers: Telegonus [or Telegonos; accept Telegony or Telegoneia]
parts: Name this man born on the island of Aeaea (ee-EE-uh). After landing in what he thinks is Corfu, he killed his father with a stingray-tipped spear.
Telegonus killed his father Odysseus, while the latter fought alongside this other son of his. He had earlier helped Odysseus kill 108 suitors of his mother Penelope.
Telegonus was born from an affair between Odysseus and Circe, which began after Odysseus used this magical herb for protection against Circe's magic.

answers: equivalence point and end point [accept stoichiometric point in place of "equivalence point"]
degree of unsaturation [or unsaturation index; accept double bond equivalents or number of double bonds; prompt on number of pi bonds; prompt on conjugation]
parts: Name these two points in an assay. One of these points is theoretically defined, while the other appears as an inflection point when concentration is on the x-axis.
At the equivalence point, the amount of analyte exactly balances the amount of reagent added during this procedure, which often uses a burette.
Titration can quantify this property of various oils in terms of bromine number and iodine number. This property serves as a proxy for an oil's propensity to oxidize when exposed to air.
Name this story collected in Bayou Folk, in which Armand sends his wife away from L'Abri upon discovering that his child is not white.
In this story by the author of "Désirée's Baby," Mrs. Mallard dies right after hearing that her husband was not really killed in a railroad accident.
This author of "The Story of An Hour" included Creole French in her novel The Awakening.

answers: Chartism [accept answers like the People's Charter]
old-age pension [accept social security for the elderly or welfare for old people or equivalents; prompt on social security or welfare by asking, "for whom?"]
parts: A third of Britain's adult population signed an 1842 petition supporting this movement for universal male suffrage. This movement's name comes from an 1838 text co-written by William Lovett.
Some 18,000 people from this constituent country of the UK signed a 1689 petition to abolish the unpopular Council of the Marches. Its capital is Cardiff.

Until a 2019 anti-Brexit petition, a 1939 petition advocating for one of these schemes was likely the most-signed in British history. The first state-sponsored program of this type was introduced by Otto von Bismarck in 1889.

answers: steel [accept stainless steel or COR-TEN steel; prompt on metal; do not accept "iron"]
parts: Identify this material used for Jeff Koons' balloon dog sculptures. The American Bridge Company fabricated a sculpture made from this material in Chicago for Pablo Picasso.
St. John's Rotary Arc was created by this artist, whose controversial site-specific Tilted Arc was removed from New York's Federal Plaza because workers in nearby buildings hated it.
Serra's fence-like sculpture Twain was commissioned for a park in this city with a view of Eero Saarinen's stainless steel Gateway Arch.

An animated neon sign nicknamed Little Audrey in this city was restored after public outcry in the 1970s. This Australian state capital's Old Treasury Building houses many relics from an 1850s Gold Rush.
This American state made neon its official element. In the 1950s, a neon cowboy named Vic advertised the Pioneer Club casino in this state.

The word "flour" was removed from the Farine Five Roses sign in this city following the passage of a 1977 language law. A sign for Fairmount Bagel advertises this city's characteristically sweet bagels.
Identify these things that, according to a theory by Lord Kelvin, linked together atoms. An Alexander polynomial is an invariant for these structures.
Kelvin's theory suggested that the atoms knotted together were themselves formed of these topological defects. The curl of the velocity and the circulation are used to characterize these things.
Kelvin theorized that atoms were vortices found within this substance which was believed to be the medium through which light propagated.

answers: Angola [or Republic of Angola; República de Angola]
parts: Identify this Scottish missionary and explorer who was "found" by Henry Morton Stanley in 1871.
Dr. Livingstone also appears in Namwali Serpell's novel The Old Drift, titled for a lodge on this river, which flows through Victoria Falls.

Livingstone earlier traveled from Linyanti to the capital of this modern-day country, now one of the most expensive cities in the world to live in. The Mbundu people are the largest ethnic group in this country.
Name this country in which fado music emerged during the 1820s.
Fado music is usually accompanied by the Portuguese version of this instrument, which has 12 strings. In Spain, players of this instrument use a cejilla when accompanying flamenco singers.
This medieval Portuguese capital on the Mondego River developed a distinctive style of fado music which is only performed by men wearing black capes.

answers: Associate Supreme Court Justices [prompt on justices; do not accept "Chief Justice"]
Sedition Act of 1798 [prompt on Alien and Sedition Acts of 1798]
parts: Identify these people, who preside on a body led by a Chief, such as John Marshall.
The Judiciary Act of 1801 briefly relieved Supreme Court Justices of having to perform this tiresome task, wherein judges would visit local municipalities to try cases.
While circuit riding, Samuel Chase drew the ire of Republicans for presiding over the prosecution of many Republicans under this law. James Callender was jailed under this law.

answers: neutron stars [prompt on stars or stellar remnants]
rotating [or rotation; accept equivalents like spinning or turning]
parts: Identify these phenomena that were predicted by general relativity and detected by LIGO ("LIE-go") in 2014.
In 2019, the detection event S190814bv ("S 19 08 14 bv") was attributed to a black hole merging with one of these extremely dense objects.

Observations of gravitational waves helped refine the TOV limit, which limits the mass of neutron stars that are not undergoing this process. Stars undergoing this process produce anomalously bright type Ia ("one A") supernovae because they are more massive than expected.

answers: Don Juan (“don JOO-an”) [do not accept or prompt on "Don Giovanni"]
hearts [accept "my heart" or "A heart whose love is innocent!"]
parts: Name this country that Byron called a "sad relic of departed worth" in Childe Harold's Pilgrimage. In 1824, Byron died while fighting in this country's war for independence.
In the third canto of this satirical Byron epic, the title character and his lover Haidée listen to a hymn lamenting Turkey's rule over the "Isles of Greece."

Byron addressed a ten-year old "Maid of Athens" in a poem that urges to "give back" this thing. Byron’s poem "She Walks In Beauty" ends by praising "A mind at peace with all below" and one of these things.

answers: yeshiva [or yeshivah; or yeshivot; yeshivoth; or yeshibot]
Modern Hasidism [or Hasidic Judaism or Chassidism]
parts: Identify this Hebrew term for academies where the Talmud and Torah are studied.

Jews who have undergone this coming-of-age ceremony typically attend a mesivta. Parties usually follow this ceremony, where Orthodox boys who have reached the age of 13 are called to read a section of the Torah.
Many yeshivas were founded in Poland after the rise of this Jewish movement, which was founded by Israel ben Eliezer, better known as Ba'al Shem Tov or the "Master of the Good Name."

answers: Native Americans [or American Indians; or Indigenous Americans; accept Muskogee; accept Creek; accept Spokane; prompt on Indians]
parts: Name this author who began all but the last line of the first section of her best-known poem with the title phrase, "She Had Some Horses." Carla Hayden appointed this author to a post previously held by Tracy K. Smith.

Harjo is the first U.S. Poet Laureate from this broad ethnic group. Harjo was an important figure in the late 20th century literary "Renaissance" of this ethnic group to which Sherman Alexie also belongs.
Joe Biden mistakenly said that this author was Poet Laureate at his inauguration, where this former Youth Poet Laureate read "The Hill We Climb."

answers: Mamluks [or Mameluke; or mamālīk; or mamluq; or marmeluke]
Saladin [or An-Nasir Salah ad-Din Yusuf ibn Ayyub; or Ṣalāḥ ad-Dīn Yūsuf ibn Ayyūb]
Antioch [or Antakya; or Antioch on the Orontes; or Syrian Antioch]
parts: Identify this class of people who established a namesake dynasty that controlled Egypt and parts of Syria from the 13th through 16th centuries.
Mamluks made up an important part of this man's armies. This Ayyubid sultan was victorious at the Battle of Hattin and negotiated with Richard the Lionheart during the Third Crusade.
Mamluk leader Baibars seized this crusader city in 1268, massacring all of its inhabitants. In ancient times, this city succeeded Seleucia as capital of an empire founded by Seleucus I Nicator.
Name this process which exchanges genetic material during prophase I of meiosis during synapsis.
A lack of a chiasma during crossing over often results in improper chromosomal segregation, which results in this general condition in which a cell has an abnormal amount of chromosomes.
The most well-known condition resulting from aneuploidy may be this trisomy of chromosome 21 which results in intellectual disability and almond-shaped eyes.

answers: a maid [or maidservant; or domestic servant; or kitchen maid; or milkmaid; prompt on servant]
pearl earrings [accept Girl with a Pearl Earring]
parts: Identify this profession. A woman in this profession in a blue and yellow dress fills a jug in another Vermeer painting.
In another Vermeer work, a woman in yellow holds a lute while discussing one of these objects with her maid. Slippers are visible against a black and white tiled floor in the foreground of that work.
In a 1999 novel, Tracy Chevalier imagined that the woman in a Vermeer painting titled for these type of earrings was one of Vermeer's maids.
Name this Pacific island, home to monolithic statues called moai ("moh-EYE") and named for the Christian holiday on which it was first visited by Europeans.

During an expedition to Easter Island, this Norwegian anthropologist and leader of the Kon-Tiki expedition observed Inca-like stonework which he cited to support his theory that Polynesia was settled by South Americans.
The moai-centered religion on Easter Island gave way to this cult based around an annual competition in which men competed to retrieve the first egg of the migratory sooty tern.

answers: V-2 rockets [or V-2 missiles; Vergeltungswaffe 2; or Retribution Weapon 2; or Aggregat 4; or A4; prompt on rockets or missiles]
parts: Identify these weapons, some three thousand of which were launched starting in 1944. One of these weapons was the first man-made object to breach the Karman Line.
The V-2 rocket campaign started three years after this period of heavy German aerial bombing, part of the larger Battle of Britain. This term comes from a German word for lightning.

This non-British city was the target of the greatest number of V-2 rockets during World War II. The rockets did proportionally less damage than the so-called "Spanish Fury" on this financial center in 1576.
